subhead: The most vulnerable countries, backed by European nations, pushed for more ambitious goals to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Other countries, led by China and India, sought to reopen the debate on climate finance.

Syria to join alliance against Islamic State after historic White House talks, US official says
subhead: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa's landmark visit to the Oval Office came just days after Washington removed him from its terrorism list. Sharaa's group, Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, was formerly affiliated with Al-Qaeda. He is the first Syrian leader to visit the White House since the Middle East country's independence in 1946.

title: Swedish municipalities defy the government over voluntary return assistance for immigrants
subhead: Across the Nordic country, mayors are voicing their opposition to right-wing and far-right efforts to encourage immigrants to leave. This unprecedented movement has caught the government off guard.

title: Iraq's parliamentary elections to take place under watchful eyes of Tehran and Washington
subhead: Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Sudani, a Shiite, seeks a second term as the fate of pro-Iranian militias has become a central issue in the election.

title: The nicotine lobby's secret expert
subhead: Greek cardiologist Konstantinos Farsalinos, an influential nicotine researcher, received thousands of euros from the vaping industry via an offshore company, according to documents seen by Le Monde.
byline: Eurydice Bersi,  Matthew Chapman and  Stéphane Horel

On the Syrian Golan Heights, Israel uses the same tools of repression as in the West Bank
subhead: Israel took advantage of the fall of the Assad regime to expand the area of southern Syria it has occupied since 1967. With uprootings of olive trees, arbitrary arrests and mobile checkpoints, soldiers have imposed a similar regime to that enforced on the population of the Palestinian territory.

title: Hors-Studio: The French duo transforming waste into design
subhead: In Rebecca Fezard and Elodie Michaud's workshop near Tours, these two researchers and sustainability enthusiasts transform leather scraps and oyster shells into biomaterials, which they use to make chairs that look like fossils and tables that seem to emerge from a block of stone.

title: François Ozon: 'No matter how big or small the film, I have always followed my own desire'
subhead: 'I wouldn't be where I am today if...' In this series, Le Monde interviews a figure about a decisive moment in their life. As a child, the director of 'The Stranger' discovered the world through his father's Super 8 films.
